5.text:
Today I am here to tell the British people
that a future Conservative government will

13.text:
have no greater priority than to protect,
support and invest in our NHS.

28.text:
In 1948, the greatest of all Conservatives
Winston Churchill supported the then Labour

36.text:
government in its plan to set up a National
Health Service. He said ‘disease must be

43.text:
attacked whether it occurs in the poorest
or richest man or woman simply on the grounds

49.text:
that it is the enemy.’
That safety net Churchill wanted is our NHS

57.text:
today, supported across the political spectrum.
Last week Labour tried to paint a different

64.text:
picture.
They know this government increased the NHS

70.text:
budget despite the financial mess Labour left
behind.

73.text:
They know the NHS has more doctors and more
nurses than ever before.

77.text:
They know fewer people than ever are waiting
long periods for their operations.

82.text:
They know the culture is becoming more caring.
But they still seek to trick the public into

89.text:
thinking one party cares for the NHS and the
other doesn’t.

95.text:
Well I have a message for Mr Miliband.
It’s not a Labour Health Service or a Conservative

102.text: Health Service…it is a National Health Service.

115.text: And when my father was cared for by a district

117.text:
nurse or my wife had our baby this summer
or our son goes for his jabs, they aren’t

123.text:
Conservative patients, Labour patients or
LibDem patients, they’re NHS patients.

129.text:
When people in this hall volunteer to support
the local league of friends or join the board

134.text:
of a hospital we’re not Conservative supporters
- we’re NHS supporters.

140.text:
We all support the NHS because the NHS is
there for us all.

145.text:
So don’t turn the National Health Service
into a National Political Football and don’t

150.text:
use the NHS to divide us when it’s the fabric
that unites our nation.

165.text:
This morning the Prime Minister announced
plans to make it easier for millions of people

171.text:
to get 8 till 8 and weekend appointments with
their GPs.

174.text:
And I want to start today by celebrating that
and some of the other successes of our NHS,

182.text:
doing so well despite huge pressure.
Take cancer, our biggest killer.

191.text:
Every family in the country has lost a friend
or loved-one to cancer - I lost my own father

199.text:
last year. It is a ruthlessly indiscriminate
killer - whether it targets someone who has

206.text:
just retired after a life of hard work or
a child with a life stretching out in front

214.text:
of them.
In 2010 this country had amongst the lowest

219.text:
cancer survival rates in Western Europe.
So we set up the cancer drugs fund. We’ve

225.text:
transformed cancer diagnosis so the NHS now
tests 1000 more people for cancer every single

232.text:
day. And so far this parliament we have treated
nearly three quarters of a million more people

238.text:
for cancer than the last one – that’s
thousands of lives saved, thousands of families

243.text:
kept together, thousands of tragedies averted.
So let’s hear it for our brilliant cancer

258.text: Or look at dementia, one of the most terrifying

263.text:
conditions of all.
I’ll never forget the courage of man I met

268.text:
with dementia who single handedly stood up
to the banks and demanded they gave him an

276.text:
alternative to having to remember a pin number.
But it isn’t just your pin number that goes.

282.text:
It’s precious family memories, marriages
of many years, relationships with children

289.text:
– all snatched away by cruel tricks of the
mind.

294.text:
When we came to office fewer than half of
those with dementia got a diagnosis, meaning

300.text:
many missed out on vital medicine or support
for their family.

304.text:
We’ve now diagnosed an extra 80,000 people.
The Prime Minister hosted a G8 summit to get

310.text:
the drug companies to do more to find a cure.
And we’re working with the Alzheimers Society

315.text:
to enroll one million dementia friends to
tackle stigma - with half a million signed

320.text:
up so far.
So let’s hear it for GPs, dementia nurses,

323.text:
dementia carers, dementia friends and people
with dementia who are changing the way our

337.text: Or A & E, the critical frontline for the NHS.

342.text:
A young A & E doctor told me how she had cried
after seeing a 90 year old man say his goodbyes

355.text:
to a 90 year old woman he’d been married
to for over 60 years.

361.text:
For her that was just part of the job. And
with a million more people using A & E, the

369.text:
pressures on her and her colleagues are immense.
Sometimes, yes, it’s been tough meeting

375.text:
the target.
But despite that we have halved the time people

379.text:
wait to be assessed and are treating nearly
2,000 more people every day within the four

385.text:
hour target compared to 2010.
So let’s hear it for our brilliant A & E

388.text:
frontline staff now preparing for a challenging
winter.

401.text:
Conference our opponents say the NHS is in
decline. But according to the independent

407.text:
Commonwealth Fund under this government the
NHS became the top-rated healthcare system

413.text:
in the world. Better than America, better
than France, better than Germany, better than

418.text:
Australia.
And the way they rose to the challenge of

422.text:
Ebola says it all - with 164 NHS volunteers
offering to go and help contain the outbreak

429.text:
in West Africa.
So let’s hear it for all NHS doctors, nurses,

438.text: porters, cleaners, caterers, carers and volunteers.

445.text: You are the best of British and the pride

449.text:
of our nation.
But that doesn’t mean things are perfect.

459.text:
About the first thing I did as Health Secretary
was to read the original Francis report about

468.text:
the terrible things that happened at Mid Staffs
Hospital between 2005 and 2009.

476.text:
I was utterly horrified.
As Francis made clear, system-wide failings

484.text:
meant these problems weren’t limited to
one hospital.

488.text:
One member of the public wrote to me about
what happened somewhere else in a letter that

496.text:
was so shocking I asked to meet her.
She said she visited her late husband in hospital

504.text:
at 5 in the morning and found him naked on
a deflated mattress, caked in urine and excrement,

512.text:
and curled in a foetal position with a cold
air conditioner blowing directly onto his

518.text:
body.
She still has nightmares about that visit.

524.text:
Now that story, thankfully, is far from typical
of our NHS.

531.text:
But I vowed that day that if I did nothing
else, I would make sure I returned a culture

537.text:
of compassionate care to every corner of our
NHS. Because caring is what the NHS stands

544.text:
for, what every doctor and nurse passionately
wants, why the NHS was set up – and what

549.text:
a quagmire of targets, goals and plans too
often allowed to be squashed.

556.text:
Supported by a wonderfully committed ministerial
team - Freddie Howe, Norman Lamb, Dan Poulter,

563.text:
Jane Ellison and George Freeman - we’re
changing things.

567.text:
We introduced a tough new inspection regime.
Since then our hospitals have hired over 5,000

579.text:
more nurses to tackle the scandal of short-staffed
wards; 5 hospitals – Basildon, North Lincs,

585.text:
George Eliot, Bucks and East Lancashire - have
been put into special measures and been turned

591.text:
round; and patients are saying that they are
treated with dignity and respect not just

596.text:
at Mid Staffs but across the NHS the highest
numbers ever recorded.

601.text:
Indeed on Friday of last week the CQC announced
the first hospital in the country to get an

608.text:
‘outstanding’ rating, Frimley Park in
Camberley. Chief Executive Andrew Morris is

622.text:
so committed he has been there for 25 years
and his son even works there as a porter.

630.text:
Well done to Frimley Park.
Now the problems of poor care highlighted

641.text:
by Robert Francis happened under Labour - so
I thought Labour would rush to support me

648.text:
in sorting them out.
In fact they did the opposite.

654.text:
They said talking about poor care was ‘running
down the NHS.’ They even tried to vote down

661.text:
the law setting up a new Chief Inspector of
Hospitals.

665.text:
I’ll tell you what ‘running down the NHS’
is:

669.text:
It’s not learning the lessons when a mother
is forced to give birth on a toilet seat,

673.text:
as happened in 2007. Ignored by Labour, being
sorted out by us.

678.text:
It’s making hospitals Foundation Trusts
even when their mortality rates are too high.

683.text:
Brushed aside by Labour, being sorted out
by us.

686.text:
It’s stopping the CQC telling the truth
about blood-stained floors in one hospital.

691.text:
Happened under Labour, stopped by us.
It happened in England before and it’s happening

696.text:
in Labour-run Wales today – so don’t you
dare talk to us about running down the NHS.

702.text:
Because for Labour good headlines about the
NHS matter more than bad care for patients

708.text:
- and in our NHS nothing matters more than
patients and whilst I am running it nothing

724.text: I simply say this to a Labour Party that still

729.text:
refuses to learn the lessons of Mid Staffs,
until you do, you are not fit to run our NHS.

737.text:
And if you won’t put patients first we will
- and it will be the Conservative Party that

742.text:
completes Nye Bevan’s vision for an NHS
that treats every patient with dignity and

747.text:
respect.
We will finish the job.

759.text:
I could go on with my concerns about the culture
Labour left behind in our NHS. But I want

765.text:
to look forward and deal with one of the biggest
concerns people have about the NHS which is

771.text:
about funding.
Labour talked about putting in more money

775.text:
last week.
But securing the NHS budget isn’t about

780.text:
an extra billion here or there.
It’s about funding over £100bn, which is

787.text:
what we spend on the NHS every year.
And that needs a strong economy. Because it’s

794.text:
very simple: you can’t fund the NHS if you
bankrupt the economy.

800.text:
This parliament we’ve actually increased
spending on the NHS by more – in real terms

806.text:
- than Labour promised last week.
We’ve done it because of David Cameron’s

812.text:
personal commitment to the NHS and difficult
decisions taken by George Osborne.

819.text:
Other countries followed Labour’s advice.
They ducked those decisions. They had no plan

824.text:
- and ended up cutting their health budgets.
Italy by 3%, Greece by 14%, Portugal by 17%.

837.text:
I don’t want that to happen here.
So never forget we’ve just had the greatest

843.text:
squeeze on finances in NHS history because
a Labour government lost control of our national

849.text:
finances.
So to anyone worried about investment in the

852.text:
NHS I say this: a Labour government with reckless
economic policies is the biggest single danger

859.text: to funding our NHS. Do not take that risk.

872.text: Nor should we forget that every penny of NHS

876.text:
funding comes not from the government but
out of the pockets of hard working taxpayers.

884.text:
So if we increase spending on the NHS we must
also look every one of them in the eye and

892.text:
promise that every penny is being spent wisely.
Which means we mustn’t stop new ideas that

899.text:
come from outside the NHS – whether from
charities or, yes, the independent sector.

907.text:
Labour call this privatisation.
But using a charity like WhizzKids to supply

912.text:
wheelchairs to disabled children or using
Specsavers to speed up the supply of glasses

918.text:
is not privatisation.
When the last Labour government used the independent

923.text:
sector to bring down waiting times that wasn’t
privatisation either.

927.text:
So stop scaremongering about privatisation
that isn’t happening. It nearly cost us

932.text:
Scotland - and we won’t let it poison the
debate in England as well.

945.text:
Secure NHS funding backed by a strong economy
is the foundation.

952.text:
But the building blocks to a modern health
service are two things that need real cultural

959.text:
change.
Personal care - a real challenge as patients

964.text:
navigate one of the biggest organisations
in the world.

968.text:
And personal control - in a world which has
too often said the doctor, not the patient,

975.text:
knows best.
I remember when I did a shift in an A & E

979.text:
last year.
A 90 year old lady with dementia was brought

983.text:
in by ambulance after a fall in her care home.
She was completely motionless. She couldn’t

991.text:
talk. She couldn’t feed herself or even
drink a glass of water.

996.text:
What made it worse was that in that A & E
we knew next to nothing about her. We didn’t

1003.text:
have her medical record. We didn’t know
her allergies. We didn’t know if she was

1007.text:
normally able to talk or whether it was just
because of the fall.

1011.text:
To us at that hospital she was not just unknown.
She was anonymous.

1017.text:
How could we possibly give her the personal
care she desperately needed?

1022.text:
The same could happen to any one of half a
million over 90s in our society.

1027.text:
And it could happen to anyone with long term
or mental health conditions, anyone of whom

1033.text:
can find themselves anonymously pushed from
pillar to post in a system that doesn’t

1038.text:
know who they are.
But for me the point of the NHS is to make

1044.text:
sure all everyone gets truly personal care
from people who know about them, know about

1051.text:
their condition, know about their care plan
- so that what happened in that A & E never

1056.text:
happens again.
As a first step that needs the integration

1062.text:
of the health and social care systems. And
for the first time ever this year it is happening.

1068.text:
150 local authority areas working together
with their local NHS on their Better Care

1073.text:
plans to pool commissioning, reduce emergency
admissions and share medical records all starting

1079.text:
from next April - with many of you in this
hall involved.

1085.text:
But truly personal care means more than joining
up health and social care.

1092.text:
It means personal, responsive care from your
GP too.

1098.text:
Last year I manned the phones in a busy London
GP practice.

1102.text:
The doctors there worked very hard. But what
was frustrating was having to tell nearly

1107.text:
every caller there were no appointments available
for two to three weeks.

1112.text:
We urgently need to make it easier for busy,
working people to get an appointment.

1125.text:
That means more GPs, so I can today confirm
plans to train and retain an extra 5,000 GPs.

1140.text:
But it also means new ways of working.
Last year we announced plans for 7.5 million

1147.text:
patients to get weekend and 8 till 8 appointments.
Today we have also announced we are rolling

1153.text:
that out to millions more – meaning this
service will be available for a quarter of

1160.text:
the whole population. And going even further,
I commit that at the end of the next parliament

1166.text:
a Conservative government will make sure every
NHS patient across the whole country will

1172.text:
be able to get weekend and 8 till 8 GP appointments.
But personal care isn’t just about a convenient

1188.text:
appointment. It means talking to a doctor
who knows about you and your condition.

1196.text:
Astonishingly in 2004 Labour abolished the
requirement for every patient to have their

1202.text:
own, named, personal GP. At a stroke, many
patients were told they no longer had their

1208.text:
own GP, but were merely attached to a surgery.
And GPs were told they were no longer personally

1215.text:
responsible for patients.
If you have a chronic condition or complex

1220.text:
needs, continuity of care is absolutely vital.
You don’t want to have to explain everything

1227.text:
about yourself over and over again - and you
want a doctor who takes ongoing responsibility

1232.text:
for sorting things out - not just that day
but every day.

1236.text:
So last year I changed that back for over
75s by insisting they get a GP named on their

1242.text:
medical record and responsible for their care.
Today I can go further and announce that in

1247.text:
the new GP contract for 2015 every single
person in England will go back to having a

1253.text:
family doctor named on their record and responsible
for their care.

1258.text:
Personal care for every NHS patient - delivered
by this government.

1271.text:
People want personal care. But in the 21st
century they want something else. Not just

1276.text:
personal care but personal control.
People with diabetes, or a heart condition,

1283.text:
or recovering from a stroke say the best person
to take control of your care is not actually

1288.text:
your doctor – it’s you.
And right now we make that far too hard.

1293.text:
We don’t give people enough information.
So this summer we became the first country

1299.text:
in the world to publish detailed information
about safety, waiting times, patient experience

1304.text:
and food for every major hospital. And on
the new MyNHS website we’ll go further.

1311.text:
But it isn’t just information about your
local hospital you want, it’s information

1316.text:
about you.
So today I can confirm that by April next

1321.text:
year, every patient in England will be able
to access their own medical record online

1327.text:
– the first country in the world to take
this huge step.

1341.text:
It means you will no longer have to pay to
access your medical record. You’ll be able

1346.text:
to see it and show it to anyone you choose.
You’ll find it easier to do detailed research

1350.text:
about your condition and easier to challenge
decisions. Because the boss is not the doctor

1356.text:
– it’s you.
Nothing about me without me.

1359.text:
Personal control of your health delivered
by this government.

1371.text:
Conference my vision is simple.
We in this party have always believed passionately

1379.text:
we should honour our debt to previous generations.
So I want Britain to be the best country in

1386.text:
the world to grow old in.
I want us to enjoy the fruits of prosperity,

1391.text:
yes, but never forget the people before us
who’ve worked hard to make that possible.

1398.text:
Never forget that all our success, all our
strength, all our wealth as a country is but

1403.text:
a hollow dream if at the end of it we are
not able to give all our citizens the healthcare

1408.text:
and support they need in old age.
Never forget that it’s not a choice between

1413.text:
a strong economy or a strong NHS. You need
both and only one party – this party – can

1419.text:
deliver both.
A strong NHS. A strong economy. From a Conservative

1432.text:
party proudly rebuilding a strong country.
Personal care. Personal control. For patients

1439.text:
treated with dignity, compassion and respect.
Delivered by our party. For our NHS. For our
